study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of hesperidin in normalizing metabolic abnormalities in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Hesperidin supplementation significantly improved fasting glucose, triglyceride levels, systolic blood pressure, and inflammatory markers (TNF-α and hs-CRP) compared to placebo, demonstrating beneficial effects on metabolic and inflammatory parameters in MetS patients.
population_specificity: 49 patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of hesperidin supplementation in improving blood glucose control in adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that hesperidin supplementation had no significant effect on fasting blood glucose, plasma insulin, glycated hemoglobin A1c, insulin resistance, or insulin sensitivity in adults. The results were consistent across different study designs, durations, and participant health statuses.
population_specificity: Adults (318 participants across six trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hesperidin could mitigate methotrexate-induced impairments in hippocampal neural stem cell proliferation and neuronal apoptosis.
results_summary: Hesperidin co-treatment with methotrexate upregulated markers of neural stem cell proliferation (SOX2, nestin, VR Ki-67) and anti-apoptotic proteins (Bcl-2, PSD-95), while suppressing pro-apoptotic markers (Bax, caspase-3). The results suggest Hesperidin effectively counteracts methotrexate-induced neurotoxicity.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats (n=24)
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg Hesperidin (daily for 21 days); 75 mg/kg methotrexate (days 8 and 15)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of hesperidin supplementation on inflammatory markers through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Hesperidin significantly reduced VCAM-1 levels but had no significant effect on CRP, E-selectin, IL-6, or ICAM-1, except for subgroup analyses showing CRP reduction in parallel-design studies and those with >4 weeks follow-up.
population_specificity: 296 participants across six RCTs (specific demographics not detailed).
study_duration: Varied, with some studies exceeding 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether hesperidin could reduce symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (SIH) and improve treatment outcomes in ischemic stroke patients receiving rt-PA therapy.
results_summary: Combined rt-PA and hesperidin treatment significantly improved outcomes, including better TCD and NIHSS scores, reduced SIH incidence, and favorable changes in TGF-β1, MMP-2, and MMP-9 levels. Follow-up hesperidin treatment for 7 days further enhanced recovery, as indicated by multiple clinical scales.
population_specificity: Patients with ischemic stroke
study_duration: Initial administration followed by 7 consecutive days of treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of hesperidin supplementation on blood pressure and inflammatory markers in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Hesperidin supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure, mean arterial blood pressure, IL-6, and hs-CRP while increasing total antioxidant capacity compared to baseline. The hesperidin group showed significant improvements in blood pressure and inflammatory markers relative to the placebo group.
population_specificity: 64 patients with type 2 diabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of hesperidin supplementation on glycemic parameters, oxidative DNA damage, and lipid peroxidation in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Hesperidin supplementation significantly increased total antioxidant capacity (TAC) and reduced serum fructoseamin, 8-hydroxydeoxyguanosine (8-OHDG), and malondialdehyde (MDA) levels in type 2 diabetes patients compared to placebo. The results suggest hesperidin may improve antioxidant status and mitigate oxidative stress markers in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (n=64).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of hesperidin 2S supplementation on endothelial function in overweight individuals, particularly its potential to mitigate endothelial dysfunction induced by a high-fat meal.
results_summary: Hesperidin 2S did not significantly improve fasting or postprandial flow-mediated dilation (FMD) in the overall study population but showed a trend toward reducing adhesion molecules (sVCAM-1, sICAM-1, sP-selectin) and blood pressure (SBP, DBP). In subjects with baseline FMD ≥3%, hesperidin protected against postprandial endothelial dysfunction and significantly downregulated adhesion molecules.
population_specificity: Overweight individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the viability of the 7F2 preosteoblast cell line following the application of a roselle flower nanoemulsion extract (RNE) to assess its potential for bone regeneration.
results_summary: The study found that RNE was nontoxic to the 7F2 preosteoblast cell line, with the highest cell viability (89.27%) observed at a 0.78% concentration on day 7, while the lowest viability (2.60%) occurred at a 100% concentration.
population_specificity: 7F2 preosteoblast cell line (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective mechanism of Hibiscus sabdariffa (HS) calyxes ethanol extract against fluoranthene (Flu)-induced toxicity in human keratinocytes.
results_summary: HS pre-treatment restored Flu-induced cell viability by reducing oxidative stress, enhancing antioxidant mechanisms, modulating xenobiotic receptors, and reversing altered gene expression related to gluconeogenesis and ferroptosis. HS constituents showed phytoestrogenic potential and effectively mitigated Flu-induced keratinocyte damage.
population_specificity: Human keratinocyte HaCaT cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antitumor effects of anthocyanins from Hibiscus sabdariffa, both alone and as adjuvants to chemotherapy, focusing on their antioxidant, antiproliferative, and immunomodulatory properties.
results_summary: The study found that anthocyanins from Hibiscus sabdariffa exhibited significant antioxidant activity, dose-dependent inhibition of cancer cell proliferation in vitro, and reduced tumor growth in vivo, especially when combined with doxorubicin, enhancing immune activation and long-term immune memory.
population_specificity: Mouse tumor models (MCA-205 fibrosarcoma and CT26 colon carcinoma cell lines)
interactions: Enhanced efficacy when combined with doxorubicin

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antibacterial properties of Hibiscus sabdariffa calyces against multidrug-resistant (MDR) clinical bacterial isolates and identify its bioactive compounds.
results_summary: The hydroethanolic extract of H. sabdariffa calyces demonstrated potent antibacterial activity against MDR clinical isolates (A. baumanii, E. coli, K. pneumoniae, and P. aeruginosa), with significant volatile organic compounds identified via GC-MS. In silico analysis showed strong binding affinities of these compounds to bacterial targets, enhancing their antibacterial effects.
population_specificity: Selective MDR clinical bacterial isolates (A. baumanii, E. coli, K. pneumoniae, and P. aeruginosa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial activity of 1% Roselle flower (Hibiscus sabdariffa) nanoemulsion extract against peri-implantitis bacteria in orthodontic mini-implants.
results_summary: The 1% Roselle flower nanoemulsion extract showed antibacterial activity against peri-implantitis bacteria (Prevotella intermedia, Porphyromonas gingivalis, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, and Fusobacterium nucleatum) at a concentration of 3.125%, though its efficacy was lower than doxycycline. The extract contained flavonoids, quinone, saponin, alkaloids, tannins, terpenoids, and steroids.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial cultures)
effective_dosage: 1% nanoemulsion extract, concentration of 3.125% for antibacterial activity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Hibiscus macranthus and Basella alba aqueous extracts on male reproductive function in rats.
results_summary: The extract from fresh leaves significantly increased body weight, seminal vesicle weight, and testosterone levels, while histological analysis showed abundant spermatozoa in treated rats. Prostatic acid phosphatase activity was also elevated in treated rats.
population_specificity: Mature male albino Wistar rats (180-220 g)
effective_dosage: 0.720 g/kg body weight (fresh leaves), 0.108 g/kg body weight (dry leaves)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the microbiological properties and antioxidant activity of beef sausage enriched with Hibiscus sabdariffa extract to improve quality and safety during storage.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa extract exhibited significant antioxidant activity and effectively inhibited bacterial growth (S. aureus, S. typhimurium, E. coli) in beef sausage during storage, though free extract performed better than encapsulated extract. Bacterial inhibition lasted until day 20 for both forms, with S. aureus appearing later in storage.
population_specificity: Beef sausage (in vitro and storage testing)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of Hibiscus sabdariffa Linn. in treating obesity.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant clinical benefit of H. sabdariffa extract in reducing body weight, BMI, or waist circumference compared to controls. No safety concerns were reported.
population_specificity: 339 participants across six randomized controlled trials.
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied between extract capsules and tea).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the nephroprotective effects of flavonoid-rich extracts from Hibiscus sabdariffa leaves in diabetic rats with kidney damage.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa leaf extracts significantly improved renal health by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and kidney dysfunction, as evidenced by biochemical and gene expression markers. The extracts also enhanced kidney morphology and mitigated diabetic nephropathy.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
effective_dosage: Low dose (LDHSFL) and high dose (HDHSFL) of flavonoid-rich extracts (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract as an adjunct to valsartan in treating high blood pressure and improving renal and metabolic markers in patients with mild chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: The HS group showed significant reductions in blood pressure and lipid profile compared to the control group, though no significant differences were observed in renal markers. Molecular docking analysis indicated that HS compounds had greater ACE inhibitory potential than hydrochlorothiazide.
population_specificity: Patients with mild chronic kidney disease and high blood pressure in Gorgan, Iran.
effective_dosage: 350 mg HS pill every 12 hours, alongside 40 mg valsartan every 12 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hibiscus sabdariffa L. could be used to synthesize MgO and Fe2O3 nanoparticles (NPs) and assess their effects on vitamin D3, calcium levels, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) in osteoporosis.
results_summary: The study found that green synthesis of MgO and Fe2O3 NPs from Hibiscus sabdariffa L. was successful. MgO NPs significantly elevated vitamin D3 and calcium levels in osteoporosis patients compared to healthy volunteers.
population_specificity: Osteoporosis patients (n=35) and healthy volunteers (n=25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities of Hibiscus sabdariffa in alloxan-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA) and enhanced antioxidant levels (GSH, SOD, CAT), while also decreasing inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β) in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with alloxan-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa on oral pathogenic bacteria responsible for dental caries and periodontal disease.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa significantly inhibited the growth and biofilm formation of all tested oral pathogenic bacterial strains, with delphinidin-3-sambubioside identified as a key inhibitory component. These findings suggest potential for developing therapeutic or preventive agents against oral diseases.
population_specificity: Oral pathogenic bacterial strains (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary supplementation with Hibiscus sabdariffa extract on working memory and blood glucose levels in diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that diabetic rats consuming the Hibiscus sabdariffa extract showed improved performance in memory tests and some exhibited normalized blood glucose levels, though results were mixed. Histological differences in the hippocampus were also observed between treated and untreated diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetic hyperglycemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Hibiscus sabdariffa (HS) on blood pressure, lipid profiles, glycemic control, and other cardiometabolic parameters.
results_summary: HS dose-dependently reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, improved lipid profiles (lowered total cholesterol and LDL-C, increased HDL-C), and showed modest glycemic benefits. A minor, clinically insignificant increase in aspartate aminotransferase was observed without elevated adverse event risks.
population_specificity: 1797 participants across 26 randomized controlled trials, with notable effects in individuals over 50 years.
effective_dosage: Dose-dependent effects noted, but specific dosage not provided in abstract.
study_duration: Trials lasting over four weeks showed stronger effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of methanolic extract of Hibiscus sabdariffa (MEHS) on Kiss1 gene expression in the rat hypothalamus to understand its potential reproductive effects.
results_summary: High-dose MEHS (400 mg/kg) downregulated Kiss1 gene expression compared to the control group, but no significant changes were observed in antioxidant levels or histopathology. The effect on Kiss1 gene expression was not linked to oxidative profile or histology.
population_specificity: Male rats with an average weight of 148 g.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg, administered orally once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the absorption and metabolism of bioactive compounds in Hibiscus sabdariffa drink and compare it to a control drink in humans.
results_summary: The study detected 38 compounds in the Hibiscus drink, with hibiscus acid being the most abundant. Metabolites derived from phenolic compounds and organic acids were identified in urine and plasma, suggesting potential anti-inflammatory bioactivity.
population_specificity: Twelve human volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-cancer potential of Hibiscus sabdariffa (HS) by examining its phytochemicals and their effects on cancer cell proliferation, apoptosis, and intracellular signaling pathways.
results_summary: The study found that HS extracts contain various phytochemicals that reduce cancer cell proliferation, induce apoptosis, and cause cell cycle arrest. These effects are mediated through increased expression of cell cycle inhibitors (p53, p21, p27) and pro-apoptotic proteins (BAD, Bax, caspases).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal studies implied, but not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypolipidemic, antioxidant, and antihypertensive effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa calyx extracts dried at different temperatures in hypertensive rats.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa extract significantly reversed hypertension-induced increases in cholesterol, triglycerides, LDL, oxidative stress markers, and blood pressure while improving HDL, antioxidant enzyme activity, and nitric oxide levels. The effects varied with drying temperatures, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for cardiovascular conditions.
population_specificity: Hypertensive rats induced with L-NAME.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and neuroprotective effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa calyx extracts in rats exposed to aluminum chloride-induced oxidative stress and neurotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa extracts significantly reversed oxidative stress markers (e.g., increased GSH, GPx, SOD, CAT) and neurotoxic effects (e.g., reduced acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase inhibition) in rat brains, with the highest efficacy observed at 30°C drying temperature and doses of 500 and 1000 mg/kg.
population_specificity: Wistar albino male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract in synthesizing copper oxide nanoparticles (CuONPs) for wastewater pollutant removal.
results_summary: The study found that CuONPs synthesized using Hibiscus sabdariffa extract effectively reduced biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and chemical oxygen demand (COD) by 56%, and significantly lowered total dissolved matter (TDS) and conductivity by 99%. The nanoparticles also removed chromium, copper, and chloride with efficiencies of 26%, 78.8%, and 78.2%, respectively.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review preclinical and clinical studies on Hibiscus sabdariffa's potential as a prophylactic and therapeutic agent for cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa contains bioactive compounds with anti-hyperlipidemia, anti-hyperglycemia, anti-hypertension, antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and anti-fibrosis effects, suggesting cardiovascular protective benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of preclinical and clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hibiscus sabdariffa ethanol extract (HSE) could prevent homocysteine-induced liver damage in vitamin B12-deficient rats.
results_summary: HSE significantly increased vitamin B12 levels, reduced homocysteine, lowered liver damage markers, decreased inflammatory proteins (SREBP1c, NFkB, TNF-a, IL-6), and improved liver histopathology, though it did not affect GRP78 expression.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with induced vitamin B12 deficiency.
study_duration: Two treatment periods of 8 and 16 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial efficacy of Hibiscus sabdariffa L. extracts against resistant bacteria and its potential anticancer effects on Caco-2 cells.
results_summary: The methanol extract of H. sabdariffa showed strong antibacterial activity against all tested bacteria, with the highest inhibition against E. coli, and demonstrated promising anticancer effects on Caco-2 cells with minimal cytotoxicity to Vero cells. Synergistic effects with piperacillin/tazobactam were also observed.
population_specificity: Pathogenic Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria (Enterobacter cloacae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus) and Caco-2 cancer cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified for antibacterial tests; IC50 of 17.51 ± 0.07 µg/mL for anticancer effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa (HS) in combination with other plant extracts on preventing metabolic syndrome and improving cardiovascular parameters.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that HS combined with other plant extracts improved anthropometric parameters, blood pressure, and lipid profile (LDL cholesterol and total cholesterol) compared to a placebo. However, further research is needed to determine optimal dosage and duration.
population_specificity: 332 participants across seven randomized clinical trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the phytoestrogenic effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract (HSE) and its potential as an alternative to hormone replacement therapy (HRT) in mitigating ovarian hypofunction (OH) effects.
results_summary: The study found that HSE modulated estrogen receptor (ER) expression differently than estradiol, with ERα being more sensitive to HSE and ERβ more responsive to estradiol. These results suggest HSE may offer a nutrition-based alternative to HRT for managing OH-related cognitive and reproductive impairments.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of biotic and abiotic inducers to enhance systemic resistance in roselle (Hibiscus Sabdariffa) against root rot and wilt diseases.
results_summary: The study found that biotic inducers like Gliocladium catenulatum and Bacillus subtilis, as well as abiotic inducers like potassium silicate and salicylic acid, significantly reduced fungal growth and disease incidence in roselle. Combined treatments showed the highest efficacy in disease control and improved plant growth, yield, and defense enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Roselle plants (Hibiscus Sabdariffa) affected by root rot and wilt diseases.
effective_dosage: Biotic inducers (e.g., G. catenulatum at 1 × 10^9 CFU/mL, T. asperellum at 1 × 10^5 CFU/mL), abiotic inducers (e.g., potassium silicate and salicylic acid at 2000 ppm or 4 g/L), and biofertilizers (e.g., mycorrhizeen + microbein at 10 g/kg seeds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of roselle (Hibiscus sabdariffa) leaf extract on wound healing in rats.
results_summary: The 15% roselle leaf extract group showed the highest wound healing percentage (84.17%) and epithelial thickness (64.69 µm), though no statistically significant differences were found among groups. The extract demonstrated potential for wound healing, warranting further investigation.
population_specificity: Rats (30 rats divided into 5 groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal conditions for using tannase to reduce tannin levels and enhance anthocyanins in Hibiscus sabdariffa tea, while evaluating its physicochemical and α-amylase inhibitory effects.
results_summary: Tannase treatment reduced esterified catechins by 8.91%, increased non-esterified catechins by 19.76%, and raised total phenolic compounds by 8.6%, but decreased α-amylase inhibitory activity by ≈28%.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or lab-based study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ultrasound and sodium hypochlorite treatments in reducing seed decay and fungal load in Hibiscus sabdariffa seeds while assessing their impact on germination, seedling growth, and biochemical markers.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment for 60 minutes significantly reduced seed decay (3.33% vs. 56.67% in control) and fungal load, increased total phenolic content, and enhanced defense-related enzyme activity without negatively affecting seed germination or seedling growth. Sodium hypochlorite was less effective compared to ultrasound.
population_specificity: Roselle (Hibiscus sabdariffa L.) seeds
effective_dosage: 28 KHz ultrasound for 20, 40, and 60 minutes; 1.5% sodium hypochlorite for 20 minutes
study_duration: Six days of seed storage post-treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the eco-friendly synthesis of zinc oxide nanoparticles using Hibiscus sabdariffa flower extract and evaluate their antibacterial, antioxidant, and catalytic properties.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa-synthesized ZnO nanoparticles exhibited strong antibacterial activity against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, significant antioxidant properties (IC50 of 38 μg/mL), and effective catalytic performance in degrading methyl orange under UV irradiation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological activities of Hibiscus sabdariffa extracts, fractions, and hibiscus acid, focusing on extracellular matrix synthesis, anti-inflammatory effects, and antioxidative stress potential in skin cells.
results_summary: Hibiscus acid demonstrated strong antioxidative stress effects by reducing extracellular ATP secretion and carbonyl protein production while maintaining high GSH/GSSG levels. It also showed potential in promoting extracellular matrix synthesis and anti-inflammatory activity in skin fibroblasts.
population_specificity: Skin fibroblasts (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hibiscus sabdariffa extract could attenuate phenanthrene-induced toxicity in human keratinocytes (HaCaT cells) by modulating CYP1A1 activity and related pathways.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with Hibiscus sabdariffa extract restored pathological changes caused by phenanthrene exposure, including cytotoxicity, ROS generation, and mitochondrial dysfunction, by inhibiting CYP1A1 activation. Docking studies confirmed the extract's bioactive compounds effectively inhibited CYP1A1 and CYP3A4.
population_specificity: Human keratinocytes (HaCaT cells) in vitro.
effective_dosage: Not specified (ethanol extract used for pre-treatment at 6 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of methanolic extract of Hibiscus Sabdariffa (MEHS) on Kiss1 gene expression in the testis and blood of Wistar rats, as well as its impact on reproductive hormones, sperm parameters, and antioxidant levels.
results_summary: MEHS significantly increased testicular weight but did not affect sperm parameters, reproductive hormones, or antioxidant levels. It downregulated Kiss1 gene expression in the blood but not in the testis, without causing histopathological changes.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (average weight 204g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the chemical groups and components of ethanol extract of Hibiscus sabdariffa L. calyces from Indonesia and assess its potential effects for dental applications.
results_summary: The ethanol extract exhibited antibacterial activity against Streptococcus sanguinis, aided in treating oral mucosa ulceration, and inhibited alveolar bone destruction. Phytochemical screening identified saponins, tannins, phenolics, flavonoids, triterpenoids, glycosides, and 17 chemical components, with fatty acids being the most dominant.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo and in vitro studies mentioned, but no human or animal details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update the knowledge about the therapeutic effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa (roselle) in diabetes and its comorbidities based on in vitro, animal, and human studies.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa exhibits hypoglycemic, antioxidant, hypotensive, and anti-lipidemic activities, making it a promising product for preventing or treating diabetes and its accompanying diseases, either alone or as an adjunct to conventional treatments.
population_specificity: In vitro, animal, and human studies (specific populations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to scientifically verify the anticancer effect of Hibiscus sabdariffa in rats with DMBA-induced breast cancer.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa extract reduced tumor incidence by 63% and 75% at 125 and 250 mg/kg doses, respectively, decreased tumor volume by over 72%, and showed antioxidant effects by increasing SOD activity and reducing MDA levels. The optimal effect was observed at 125 mg/kg.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (~55 days old) with DMBA-induced breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dehydrated Hibiscus sabdariffa calyces (DHSC) supplementation on attenuating pre-neoplastic lesions (ACF) and related cellular responses in a colorectal cancer model.
results_summary: Supplementation with 5% and 10% DHSC significantly reduced aberrant crypt foci (ACF) and inflammatory infiltrates in the colon. The 10% DHSC group also showed increased catalase activity, butyrate production, natural killer cells, and hypertrophied goblet cells.
population_specificity: Male BALB/c mice with 1,2-dimethylhydrazine-induced pre-neoplastic lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Hibiscus sabdariffa as a natural dye source for the textile industry and its environmental benefits.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa is a rich source of anthocyanins, which can be enhanced through callus formation and sucrose concentration. The extracted dye showed variable coloring properties depending on cloth type and pH conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (industrial/environmental focus, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the best water extraction method (hot vs. cold) for Hibiscus Sabdariffa's antihypertensive metabolites and confirm their in vivo efficacy.
results_summary: Both cold and hot extracts significantly reduced hypertension-related biomarkers, with the hot extract showing superior antihypertensive and cardioprotective effects. Metabolomics revealed differences in anthocyanin and phenolic content, with higher levels of specific phenolics in the hot extract correlating with better outcomes.
population_specificity: L-NAME-induced hypertensive rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of delphinidin-3-O-glucoside (DP) from Hibiscus sabdariffa against atherosclerosis in a rabbit model.
results_summary: DP (20 mg/kg) significantly reduced serum lipid levels (TG, TC, LDL-C, HDL-C), decreased oxidative stress and inflammation markers (IL-6, VCAM-1, NF-κB), and upregulated antioxidant enzymes (GSH-PX, SOD1) in atherosclerosis-induced rabbits.
population_specificity: Rabbits fed a high-fat diet to induce atherosclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the potential benefits of co-administration of Hibiscus sabdariffa (HS) and glibenclamide in reducing oxidative stress in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: HS alone and in combination with glibenclamide significantly lowered fasting blood glucose levels and increased antioxidant enzyme activity while reducing oxidative stress markers. The combination showed beneficial regeneration of pancreatic islet cells and was more effective than either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Male albino Wistar rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.
effective_dosage: 500mg/kg body weight of HS, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of roselle calyx beverages on blood pressure, abdominal circumference, BMI, hematological and urinary parameters, and lipid profile in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in high-density lipoprotein levels, blood pressure, and abdominal circumference, but no significant changes in total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein, BMI, or urinalysis parameters. No serious adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects (n=30)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Hibiscus sabdariffa in reducing blood pressure in patients with mild-to-moderate hypertension or metabolic syndrome (MetS) compared to placebo, antihypertensive drugs, or other herbal products.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to placebo but was not superior to antihypertensive drugs or effective in patients with MetS-associated hypertension. The effects were statistically significant only in patients with hypertension alone.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate hypertension or hypertension associated with metabolic syndrome (MetS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Hibiscus sabdariffa in modulating cardiovascular disease risk markers, such as blood pressure, lipid profiles, and fasting plasma glucose, compared to pharmacologic, nutritional, or placebo treatments.
results_summary: Hibiscus significantly reduced systolic blood pressure compared to placebo, with the greatest effect in individuals with elevated baseline BP. It also lowered LDL cholesterol levels more effectively than other teas or placebo, while showing BP-lowering effects comparable to medication.
population_specificity: Adult populations with cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., elevated blood pressure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Hibiscus sabdariffa on the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of amlodipine in hypertensive rats.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa lowered systolic, diastolic, and mean blood pressure, and enhanced the blood pressure-lowering effect of amlodipine. It also increased the AUC0-t of amlodipine, indicating improved bioavailability.
population_specificity: Hypertensive rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a nutraceutical containing Hibiscus sabdariffa and Lippia citriodora could improve appetite control and reduce calorie intake in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the Lc-Hs extract significantly decreased appetite sensation, increased satiety, and reduced calorie intake during an ad-libitum meal. It also influenced hunger-related hormones like leptin and GLP-1, suggesting a potential mechanism for appetite regulation.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (n=33, age 33.76 ± 12.23, BMI 28.20 ± 2.47 kg/m², fat mass 30.65 ± 8.39%).
study_duration: Two 60-day intervention periods separated by a 30-day washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Delphinidin-3-sambubioside (Dp3-Sam), an anthocyanin from Hibiscus sabdariffa, in preventing hyperlipidemia in vivo and in vitro.
results_summary: Dp3-Sam reduced body weight gain, visceral fat, hepatic lipid deposits, and intracellular lipid accumulation in rats and HepG2 cells. It also modulated key lipid metabolism genes and upregulated pAMPK expression, suggesting potential for improving lipid dysfunction.
population_specificity: Rats fed a high-fat diet and HepG2 cells treated with oleic acid.
effective_dosage: 100-200 µg/ml for HepG2 cells (in vitro); dosage for rats not specified.
study_duration: 8 weeks for rats; duration for HepG2 cells not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using Hibiscus sabdariffa decoction to manage hypertension in internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq.
results_summary: The study found that 61.8% of participants in the intervention group achieved target blood pressure (<140/90 mmHg) after six weeks, with significant mean reductions in systolic (23.1 mmHg) and diastolic (12.0 mmHg) blood pressure compared to the control group. The decoction contained 36 mg of total anthocyanins and 2.13 g of hibiscus acid per starting dose.
population_specificity: Internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Iraq with high blood pressure (≥140/90 mmHg).
effective_dosage: Starting dose of 10 grams per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how gut microbiota bioconverts phenolic compounds and organic acids in predigested Hibiscus sabdariffa (Hb) and its mixture with Agave fructans (AF).
results_summary: The study found that colonic fermentation of Hb produced various microbial phenolic metabolites, including derivatives of hydroxyphenylpropionic, hydroxyphenylacetic, and hydroxybenzoic acids, as well as organic acids like hydroxycitric and hibiscus acids. No differences were observed between the metabolites from Hb alone and Hb/AF mixtures.
population_specificity: In vitro model of the human colon (TIM-2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if supplementation with an HS-LC blend (MetabolAid®) could effectively treat type 1 hypertension in sedentary populations.
results_summary: The HS-LC extract significantly reduced daytime blood pressure parameters, particularly systolic blood pressure, over 84 days, while the placebo showed no such effects.
population_specificity: 80 type 1 hypertensive subjects of both sexes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a 2% Hibiscus sabdariffa L. (HSL) infusion on renal function in a metabolic syndrome rat model.
results_summary: The 2% HSL infusion reversed renal dysfunction and oxidative stress markers in metabolic syndrome rats, improving antioxidant enzyme activity, reducing lipoperoxidation, and restoring normal renal function.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced metabolic syndrome.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the medical effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa on common chronic diseases, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obesity, diabetes, and Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa demonstrated antihypertensive, antihyperlipidemic, and antihyperglycemic effects through mechanisms such as vasodilation, ACE inhibition, AMPK activation, and anti-inflammatory properties. It also showed neuroprotective effects by reducing neuroinflammation and inhibiting hyperphosphorylated tau proteins in mouse brains.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare three distillation techniques (hydrodistillation, steam distillation, and solvent-free microwave-assisted extraction) for obtaining essential oils from Hibiscus sabdariffa calyces and analyze their composition.
results_summary: The study identified 62 compounds in the essential oils, with varying compositions across the three distillation methods: hydrodistillation yielded 55 components (95.75%), solvent-free microwave-assisted extraction yielded 37 (96.06%), and steam distillation yielded 29 (99.63%). Chemometric tools were used to optimize and analyze the relationship between distillation techniques and oil composition.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on extraction methods, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Hibiscus Sabdariffa (rosella) on metabolic syndrome by examining its impact on blood nitric oxide (NO) and cortisol levels.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in body weight, blood pressure, glucose levels, lipid profile, and cortisol levels after consuming rosella tea. NO levels increased significantly, suggesting potential benefits for metabolic syndrome management.
population_specificity: Elderly women with metabolic syndrome (n=16, split into control and treatment groups).
effective_dosage: 2 grams of rosella tea, twice daily (morning and evening after meals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effectiveness of Hibiscus sabdariffa in tablet and brew forms for managing hypertension in noncomplicated hypertensive patients.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa showed significant and equivalent blood pressure reduction compared to captopril, with brews slightly more effective than tablets. Target blood pressure was achieved by 49% of patients using bissap, comparable to kinkeliba (51%) and better than captopril (40%).
population_specificity: 219 hypertensive patients (SBP 140-180 mmHg and/or DBP 90-110 mmHg) without cardiovascular or renal complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hibiscus sabdariffa extract could act as a phytoestrogen to improve spatial memory and BDNF expression in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa extract reversed the negative effects of ovariectomy on short- and long-term memory and BDNF expression, with a stronger effect observed at the lower dose (50 mg/kg). The extract demonstrated phytoestrogenic activity comparable to estradiol.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized female Wistar rats (90-day-old).
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg and 100 mg/kg body weight, administered in drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant properties of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract (free and nanoencapsulated forms) and its potential to improve the quality and shelf life of chicken nuggets during refrigerated storage.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa extract, especially in nanoencapsulated form, significantly reduced oxidative spoilage and organoleptic changes in chicken nuggets, demonstrating high antioxidant activity. The best results were observed with CMC combined with the extract or nano-extract, which delayed spoilage and improved product quality.
population_specificity: Chicken nuggets (food product study, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of roselle (Hibiscus sabdariffa) as a biological stain, particularly as a substitute for hematoxylin in nuclear staining.
results_summary: The study found that roselle, when used without oxidation and mordanting, acts as an indiscriminate oversight stain, but with proper oxidation and mordanting, it can effectively stain nuclei. The authors propose a rationally formulated stain followed by a differentiating solution to improve its utility.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory/technical application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the safety and efficacy of AqualiefTM, containing Hibiscus sabdariffa, in improving saliva pH, production, and dry mouth symptoms in xerostomia patients.
results_summary: AqualiefTM significantly increased saliva pH and production (56% unstimulated, 27% stimulated) and improved dry mouth symptoms compared to placebo, which showed minimal effects.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with xerostomia (RTOG/EORTC grade 1-2).
effective_dosage: Three tablets/day after meals (exact Hibiscus sabdariffa dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile existing evidence on the molecular mechanisms behind Hibiscus sabdariffa's anticancer potential and its implications for cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa exhibits chemopreventive, cytotoxic, and anti-metastatic effects in various human cancer cells, with polyphenolic compounds showing potent anticancer activity. However, the molecular mechanisms are not fully understood, and better-designed clinical trials are needed.
population_specificity: Human cancer cells (in vitro studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Aloe vera gel (AG) pre-harvest spray (AGSC) and postharvest dip coating (AGDC) on improving the postharvest quality and shelf life of Hibiscus Sabdariffa (HbS) microgreens.
results_summary: AG-coated microgreens showed significantly reduced postharvest deterioration and higher ascorbic acid content compared to uncoated controls. AGSC maintained better overall acceptability and postharvest quality than AGDC, particularly in retaining greenness and reducing electrolyte leakage in HbS microgreens.
population_specificity: Radish (RaS) and roselle (HbS) microgreens stored at 5 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Hibiscus sabdariffa petals on inflammation in a DSS-induced colitis mouse model by measuring cytokine expressions and histological inflammation scores.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa reduced inflammation in DSS-induced colitis mice, with significant changes in pro-inflammatory (IL-6, TNF-α) and anti-inflammatory (IL-10) cytokine expressions over time. However, its effects were less consistent than mesalazine, and histological inflammation scores were higher in the roselle-treated group initially but improved over time.
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Hibiscus sabdariffa on antihypertensive activity and the pharmacokinetics of losartan in hypertensive rats.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure in hypertensive rats and increased the plasma concentration of losartan, enhancing its antihypertensive effect. The study predicted potential herb-drug interactions between Hibiscus sabdariffa and losartan.
population_specificity: L-NAME-induced hypertensive rats (n=5 per group).
interactions: Potential interaction with losartan (increased Cmax and AUC0-t).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physicochemical properties and preservation of phenolic compounds in Hibiscus sabdariffa extracts using spray-drying with different carrier agents.
results_summary: Aqueous extracts showed the highest concentration of total soluble polyphenols (32.12-21.23 mg EAG/g DW) and antioxidant capacity in the ABTS assay. The optimal treatment (T4) used 2.5% Hibiscus w/w, aqueous extract, and specific carrier ratios.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a polyphenolic extract of Hibiscus sabdariffa (HSE) on gut microbiota, metabolic parameters, and inflammation in a diet-induced obesity mouse model.
results_summary: HSE reduced weight gain, improved glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity, normalized cholesterol ratios, reduced liver inflammation, and enhanced gut integrity. It also had a prebiotic effect, improving the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio in gut microbiota.
population_specificity: Diet-induced obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if supplementation with Hibiscus sabdariffa and Lippia citriodora is effective for obesity treatment or weight control in subjects without a controlled diet.
results_summary: The study found that intake of the extract for 84 days reduced body weight, BMI, and fat mass, particularly in the trunk area, as measured by bioimpedance and densitometry. The reduction in fat mass was significant, suggesting potential efficacy for weight management.
population_specificity: Subjects without a controlled diet (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine Hibiscus sabdariffa's potential to increase GLP-1 secretion in the ileum and its action in pancreatic β-cells, as well as identify its active ingredients interacting with SGLT-1 and GLP-1R.
results_summary: H. sabdariffa at 500 mg/kg BW restored GLP-1 levels in diabetic rats to normal levels, with active ingredients like leucosin and delphinidin binding to SGLT-1 and GLP-1R, respectively. The extract showed comparable efficacy to normal conditions in both ileum and pancreas.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats (8-10 weeks old, 200-250 g)
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg BW and 500 mg/kg BW, administered orally once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and tolerability of Hibiscus sabdariffa (karkade) tea in managing uncontrolled hypertension, with or without medication.
results_summary: The study found that 38% of participants achieved target blood pressure, and 65% experienced a systolic BP reduction of at least 10 mmHg. Hibiscus sabdariffa was generally well tolerated.
population_specificity: Thirty-eight participants with uncontrolled hypertension (BP >140/90 mmHg) outside a refugee camp in Jordan.
effective_dosage: 10 g HS/0.5 L daily, increased to 15 g HS/1 L in the second week and 20 g HS/1 L in the third week if BP remained high.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral activity of Hibiscus Sabdariffa tea extract against human influenza A virus (IAV) and assess its potential as an anti-IAV drug and a safe inactivating agent for vaccines.
results_summary: Hibiscus tea extract showed potent acid-dependent antiviral activity and weak low-pH-independent activity, but the acidic extract was ineffective for therapy or vaccination in mice. The low-pH-independent activity did not compromise the antigenicity of hemagglutinin, suggesting potential for medication and vaccination applications.
population_specificity: Mice (in vivo) and in vitro studies

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Hibiscus sabdariffa extracts as a therapy for multiple myeloma, focusing on cell viability, migration, and neurotoxicity.
results_summary: The study identified HsFC as the most effective extract, showing activity against RPMI-8226 cells without neurotoxic effects at active concentrations. Two derived compounds significantly reduced cell migration.
population_specificity: In vitro study on RPMI-8226 cell line (multiple myeloma model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare pectin extraction methods from Hibiscus sabdariffa L. by-products and evaluate their properties for potential industrial applications.
results_summary: Soaking wastes yielded higher pectin with superior properties (high methoxyl groups, galacturonic acid content, viscosity, gelling capacity) compared to decoction. Sudan cultivar pectin showed better industrial potential than citric pectin, though anthocyanins and ascorbic acid had no antimicrobial effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on plant material, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic potential of Hibiscus sabdariffa calyx extract (HSCE) by assessing its effects on pancreatic β-cell regeneration and antioxidant activity in STZ-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: HSCE treatment significantly improved antioxidant levels (glutathione, catalase, superoxide dismutase) and restored pancreatic β-cell morphology and density in diabetic rats, suggesting regenerative and antioxidant mechanisms. Histopathological and stereological analyses confirmed these improvements.
population_specificity: STZ-induced type 1 diabetic Wistar rats (n=12 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa aqueous extract (HS) alone and in combination with captopril on blood pressure and RAAS biomarkers in a rat model of hypertension.
results_summary: HS alone reduced blood pressure significantly, and coadministration with captopril also lowered blood pressure and RAAS biomarkers, though HS may not provide additional benefits beyond captopril. All treatments restored blood pressure and RAAS markers to near-normal levels.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats with induced hypertension (2K1C model).
effective_dosage: HS alone (30 mg/200 g BW); HS plus captopril (15, 30, or 60 mg/200 g BW with 4.5 mg/200 g BW captopril).
interactions: Possible interaction with captopril, but no additional benefit noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Hibiscus sabdariffa infusion (3%) could protect cardiac function during ischemia/reperfusion in a metabolic syndrome rat model by enhancing antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The HSL infusion restored cardiac mechanical performance and coronary vascular resistance, increased antioxidant enzyme activities (Mn-SOD, Cu/Zn-SOD, peroxidases, GST, GSH, TAC, NO3-/NO2-), and reduced lipoperoxidation in MS rats undergoing ischemia/reperfusion. The results suggest HSL protects cardiac function through its antioxidant properties.
population_specificity: Metabolic syndrome-induced rats (n = 6 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute impact of Hibiscus sabdariffa calyces (HSC) extract on postprandial vascular function and cardiometabolic risk factors, including blood pressure and endothelial function.
results_summary: Acute consumption of HSC extract significantly improved flow-mediated dilatation (FMD) and systemic antioxidant response, with non-significant reductions in blood pressure and favorable but non-significant changes in other cardiometabolic markers like glucose, insulin, and CRP. No significant changes in arterial stiffness were observed.
population_specificity: 25 men with 1% to 10% cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk (determined by QRISK®2).
effective_dosage: 250 mL of aqueous extract of HSC consumed once with breakfast.
study_duration: Single acute intervention with measurements taken over 4 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the health-related effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa extracts (HSE) and its main compound hydroxycitric acid (HCA) on lifespan, locomotion, and protection against amyloid-β toxicity in C. elegans, as well as the underlying molecular mechanisms involving transcription factors DAF-16 and SKN-1.
results_summary: HSE treatment significantly extended lifespan (up to 24%) and reduced age-dependent decline in locomotion in C. elegans, while HCA had a minor effect (6%). HSE also protected against amyloid-β toxicity, mediated by activation of DAF-16 and SKN-1, but increased intracellular ROS levels, suggesting a pro-oxidative effect.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a phytotherapeutic product containing Hibiscus sabdariffa, D-mannose, and Lactobacillus plantarum in preventing urinary tract infections following invasive urodynamic examination.
results_summary: The study found that the combination reduced bacteriuria and urinary tract infections, with 13% of patients developing infections, mostly among those with prior recurrent infections. No side effects were reported, and all patients completed the therapy.
population_specificity: 100 female patients aged 19-87 years who underwent invasive urodynamic procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract (HSE) on obesity-related parameters, including body weight, lipid accumulation, cholesterol metabolism, pancreatic lipase inhibition, and adipocyte differentiation.
results_summary: The study found that HSE effectively reduced body weight, inhibited lipid accumulation, suppressed adipogenesis via the PPARγ pathway, and improved cholesterol metabolism. However, toxicity was dose-dependent and prolonged use may cause adverse effects.
population_specificity: Cell and animal models, as well as humans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hibiscus sabdariffa leaf meals (HSM) could improve iron status in childbearing-age women and protect against stunting in toddlers during the dry/lean season in Northern Ghana.
results_summary: The study found that consuming HSM improved iron status in women (p = 0.011) and reduced stunting in toddlers (p = 0.024) compared to the control group. The intervention was particularly effective during the nutritionally vulnerable dry/lean season.
population_specificity: Childbearing-age women (15–49 years) and their toddlers (6–24 months) in Northern Ghana.
effective_dosage: 1.9 kg/day of HSM (1.71 mg Fe/100 g meal), consumed three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract on catalase activity and gene expression in DMBA-induced rats, as well as its impact on liver histopathology.
results_summary: Rosella extract significantly increased catalase activity and gene expression in a dose-dependent manner, with no observed liver histopathological abnormalities. The study concluded that the extract enhances catalase activity and gene expression in vivo.
population_specificity: DMBA-induced rats (animal study).
effective_dosage: 10, 50, and 100 mg/kg body weight per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a phytotherapic combination containing Hibiscus sabdariffa for treating acute episodes of uncomplicated UTIs in women with recurrent UTIs, compared to short-term antibiotic therapy.
results_summary: The phytotherapic combination improved quality of life scores similarly to antibiotics at 30 days and showed superior QoL improvement at 3 months. It also led to asymptomatic bacteriuria in 26% of patients, unlike the antibiotic group.
population_specificity: Adult females with uncomplicated UTIs and a history of recurrent UTIs.
effective_dosage: 1 tablet in the morning and 1 tablet in the evening for 7 days (exact dosage of Hibiscus sabdariffa not specified).
study_duration: 7 days of active treatment, with follow-ups at 30 days and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the encapsulation efficiency and storage stability of Hibiscus sabdariffa anthocyanins in yeast cells for color preservation.
results_summary: The study found that yeast encapsulation provided good protection for anthocyanins, especially when yeast enzymes were inactivated by heat treatment. Storage stability was significantly better at lower temperatures and acidic pH, with heat-treated yeast microparticles showing minimal color loss (2.5% at 37°C in water).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 0.5 g wet yeast cells for 5 ml of anthocyanin extracts at 1 g·L⁻¹ with 10% ethanol

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of extraction conditions on bioactive compounds in Hibiscus sabdariffa calyx, assess anthocyanin stability, and determine cytotoxic effects on tumor cell lines.
results_summary: Temperature and time significantly influenced anthocyanin and flavonoid content, while pH variations conserved antioxidant activity. The extracts showed no significant cytotoxic effects on tumor cell lines, supporting their antioxidant properties.
population_specificity: Tumor cell lines (Caco-2, HepG-2, HCT8, A549)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of aqueous extract of dried calyx of sour tea (Hibiscus Sabdariffa) on lipid profiles in adults with polygenic dyslipidemia.
results_summary: The study found that sour tea significantly reduced total cholesterol, HDL-C, and LDL-C levels by up to 9.46%, 8.33%, and 9.80%, respectively, after 12 weeks in the intervention group. However, no significant differences in lipid profiles were observed between the intervention and control groups, except for HDL-C concentrations.
population_specificity: Adults aged 30-60 years with polygenic dyslipidemia.
effective_dosage: Two cups of sour tea daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa phenolic extract on enzyme activities (AChE, BChE, MAO, E-NTDase, Na+/K+-ATPase) and oxidative damage in rat brain homogenates, assessing its potential for neurodegenerative disease treatment.
results_summary: The extract inhibited AChE, BChE, MAO, and E-NTDase while stimulating Na+/K+-ATPase, reduced oxidative damage markers (MDA), and contained high levels of phenolic compounds like catechin and chlorogenic acid, suggesting potential benefits for neurodegenerative diseases.
population_specificity: Rat brain homogenates (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: EC50 values ranged from 21.46 µg/mL to 67.12 µg/mL for various effects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the inhibitory properties of protocatechuic acid (PCA) from Hibiscus sabdariffa against jack bean urease (JBU) and its potential toxicity on human gastric epithelial cells (GES-1).
results_summary: PCA showed notable anti-JBU activity with an IC50 of 1.7 µM, outperforming acetohydroxamic acid (AHA), and exhibited no significant cytotoxicity on GES-1 cells at concentrations of 1.12–3.12 µM. Molecular docking indicated strong binding of PCA to urease, linked to its hydroxyl moieties.
population_specificity: Human gastric epithelial cells (GES-1) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the blood pressure-lowering effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa (bissap) with Combretum micranthum (kinkeliba) and ramipril in adults with non-complicated hypertension.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, though less than ramipril for systolic BP. It showed a natriuretic effect and normalized BP in 21% of patients after four weeks.
population_specificity: Adult patients with non-complicated hypertension (>140/90 mmHg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Hibiscus sabdariffa extract (HSE) could protect H9c2 cells from doxorubicin-induced cytotoxicity and apoptosis.
results_summary: Pretreatment with HSE (31.25-500 μg/mL) increased cell viability and significantly reduced apoptosis in H9c2 cells exposed to doxorubicin, suggesting cardioprotective effects via antiapoptotic activity.
population_specificity: H9c2 cells (rat cardiomyocyte cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential protective effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa L. extract against ischaemia-induced brain damage in rats, focusing on its antioxidant activity.
results_summary: Pretreatment with Hibiscus sabdariffa L. extract (HSE) significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA, GSH, SOD, CAT) and attenuated neuronal damage caused by bilateral common carotid artery occlusion (BCCAO). HSE also reversed behavioral changes induced by BCCAO, showing comparable efficacy to vitamin E.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats (n=35, divided into 5 groups of 7 rats each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neonatal intake of Hibiscus sabdariffa (HS) could protect against metabolic programming effects induced by fructose consumption later in life.
results_summary: Neonatal HS administration protected female rats against fructose-induced hypertriglyceridaemia and liver lipid deposition, while increasing plasma cholesterol concentrations. In males, HS prevented fructose-induced hypercholesterolaemia.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats (neonatal and weaned)
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg of HS aqueous calyx extract, administered orally
study_duration: Administered from postnatal day 4 to postnatal day 14, followed by a 30-day fructose intervention post-weaning

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa extracts on hyperlipidaemia and its interaction with simvastatin in animal and human models.
results_summary: Hibiscus sabdariffa extract reduced total cholesterol more effectively than simvastatin in rats and enhanced the drug's antihyperlipidaemic effects at low doses. However, in humans, the beverage significantly reduced simvastatin exposure, indicating a herb-drug interaction.
population_specificity: Hyperlipidaemia-induced Wistar rats and six healthy human volunteers.
effective_dosage: AEHS 250 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg; simvastatin 10 mg/kg and 20 mg/kg in rats; single-dose 40 mg simvastatin in humans.
study_duration: 2 and 4 weeks in rats; 24-hour pharmacokinetic analysis in humans.
interactions: Significant interaction with simvastatin, reducing its peak concentration and overall exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa aqueous extract against cyclophosphamide-induced DNA damage in male Wistar rats.
results_summary: The study found that Hibiscus sabdariffa aqueous extract reduced micronucleus frequency by 91% compared to the positive control group, demonstrating a protective effect against DNA damage and potential chemopreventive properties.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of sour tea (Hibiscus sabdariffa) supplementation on oxidative stress and muscle damage in soccer athletes compared to green tea and placebo.
results_summary: Sour tea extract (STE) significantly reduced oxidative stress (decreased MDA levels) and increased total antioxidant capacity (TAC) compared to placebo, but had no significant effect on muscle damage indices.
population_specificity: 54 male soccer players

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral activity of Hibiscus sabdariffa against HSV-2 and its anti-enzymatic activity against urease.
results_summary: The study found that protocatechuic acid (PCA) from Hibiscus sabdariffa showed potent anti-HSV-2 activity, comparable to acyclovir, and the aqueous extract exhibited anti-urease inhibition for the first time. The results suggest potential therapeutic applications for HSV-2 infection and diseases caused by urease-producing bacteria.
population_specificity: In vitro study using HSV-2 clinical isolates and Vero cells.
effective_dosage: EC50 values: PCA (0.92 µg∙mL-1), acyclovir (1.43 µg∙mL-1); IC50 for anti-urease activity: 82.4 µg∙mL-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if neonatal consumption of Hibiscus sabdariffa (HS) would have long-term effects on erythrocyte osmotic fragility (EOF) and general health in rats later fed a high-fructose diet.
results_summary: HS extracts did not alter general health or EOF in response to a high-fructose diet, indicating no long-term metabolic programming effects from neonatal HS consumption.
population_specificity: Four-day-old Sprague Dawley rat pups.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg of HS aqueous calyx extract orally.
study_duration: Administered from postnatal day 4 to day 14, followed by a 30-day fructose intervention post-weaning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa Linn (HSL) aqueous extract as an antidiabetic and antioxidant agent against oxidative liver injury in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: HSL supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, increased plasma insulin, and lowered liver enzyme levels in diabetic rats. It also mitigated liver damage, including hepatocyte destruction and mitochondrial degeneration.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract (HSE) on human tumor cell lines, specifically Multiple Myeloma (MM) and Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma (OSCC).
results_summary: HSE impaired cell growth, exerted a reversible cytostatic effect, and reduced cell motility and invasiveness in RPMI 8226 (MM) and SCC-25 (OSCC) cell lines. The cytostatic effect depended on p38 activation, while ERK1/2 modulation was crucial for cell motility and invasiveness.
population_specificity: Human tumor cell lines (RPMI 8226 and SCC-25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the antioxidant properties of Hibiscus sabdariffa Linne (HSL) infusion could improve oxidative stress in Marfan syndrome (MFS) patients.
results_summary: The study found that HSL infusion significantly decreased oxidative stress markers (ECSOD, GPx, GST, GSH, TAC, and ascorbic acid) but increased GSSG-R activity and LPO in MFS patients compared to controls. The results suggest HSL has antioxidant properties that enhance both enzymatic and nonenzymatic systems in MFS patients.
population_specificity: Marfan syndrome (MFS) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Hibiscus sabdariffa in regulating blood lipids among patients with metabolic syndrome and related disorders.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of nine trials involving 503 participants showed that Hibiscus sabdariffa supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol compared to the control group, with a weighted mean difference of -14.66 (95% CI [-18.22, -11.10]; p = .000).
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome and related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how dietary plant polyphenols, including Hibiscus Sabdariffa, counteract metabolic and oxidative stress biomarkers linked to obesity-related disorders.
results_summary: The study suggests that plant polyphenols, such as those in Hibiscus Sabdariffa, can modulate molecular targets and epigenetic modifications to counteract metabolic imbalances caused by improper diet. However, specific efficacy data for Hibiscus Sabdariffa alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a polyphenolic extract combination (Lippia citriodora and Hibiscus sabdariffa) on obesity-related metabolic disturbances in overweight/obese subjects.
results_summary: The LC-HS supplement significantly improved body weight, abdominal circumference, body fat percentage, heart rate, and systolic blood pressure in overweight subjects, with more modest effects in obese subjects. It also reduced lipid content and increased AMPK activity in adipocyte cells.
population_specificity: 56 obese/overweight subjects
effective_dosage: 500 mg/day (combination of Lippia citriodora and Hibiscus sabdariffa extracts)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential antihypertensive effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed a significant effect of Hibiscus sabdariffa in lowering both systolic and diastolic blood pressure, with effects inversely associated with baseline BP values and robust in sensitivity analyses.
population_specificity: 390 participants (225 in the Hibiscus sabdariffa group, 165 in the control group) from five RCTs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the antihypertensive effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa tisane (hibiscus tea) consumption in pre- and mildly hypertensive adults.
results_summary: Hibiscus tea significantly lowered systolic blood pressure compared to placebo, with a greater effect observed in participants with higher baseline systolic blood pressure. Diastolic blood pressure and mean arterial pressure also showed reductions, though these changes were not statistically significant compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 65 pre- and mildly hypertensive adults, aged 30-70 years, not taking blood pressure-lowering medications.
effective_dosage: 3 servings/day of 240 mL brewed hibiscus tea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective and anti-inflammatory effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract on oxidative stress and cytokine production in vitro and in humans.
results_summary: The extract protected cells from oxidative stress, modulated cytokine production (increased IL-6 and IL-8, decreased MCP-1) in vitro, and reduced plasma MCP-1 in humans without affecting other cytokines or antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: Cultured peripheral blood mononuclear cells (in vitro) and human subjects (acute dose study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanism of Higenamine (HG) in protecting against doxorubicin-induced heart failure, focusing on gut microbiota, metabolomics, and the Nrf2/GPX4 ferroptosis pathway.
results_summary: HG alleviated myocardial injury by improving cardiac and mitochondrial function, reducing oxidative stress, and promoting cell proliferation. It also modulated gut microbiota and regulated the Nrf2/GPX4 ferroptosis pathway, demonstrating anti-heart failure effects.
population_specificity: Rats and H9c2 cardiomyocytes (in vitro model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Higenamine could ameliorate depression-like behavior in rats by improving astrocyte gap junction function and reducing neuroinflammation.
results_summary: Higenamine improved depression-like behavior in rats, enhanced astrocyte gap junction function, reduced inflammation, and modulated connexin 43 expression and phosphorylation.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to chronic unpredictable stress (CUS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anabolic activity and molecular mechanisms of Higenamine in C2C12 myotubes, focusing on its potential performance-enhancing effects.
results_summary: Higenamine significantly increased myotube diameters and stimulated mRNA expression of hypertrophy-related genes. Its effects were antagonized by ER and AR inhibitors but not by an ADRB2 inhibitor, suggesting interactions with AR and ER pathways rather than β2-adrenoceptor activation.
population_specificity: Differentiated C2C12 myotubes (in vitro cell model).
effective_dosage: Dose-dependent effects were analyzed, but specific dosage amounts are not provided.
interactions: Antagonistic activity with AR and ER; potential cross-talk with these receptors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Higenamine in treating ulcerative colitis and its underlying mechanism, focusing on the Galectin-3/TLR4/NF-κB pathway.
results_summary: Higenamine improved symptoms and pathological changes in DSS-induced UC mice and NCM460 cells, reduced inflammation and apoptosis, and restored mucosal barrier integrity by inhibiting the Galectin-3/TLR4/NF-κB pathway. Galectin-3 overexpression reversed these effects in vitro.
population_specificity: DSS-induced ulcerative colitis mice and DSS-induced NCM460 human colon epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify higenamine as an antibacterial agent against Fusobacterium nucleatum and optimize its derivatives for improved anti-F. nucleatum activity in colorectal cancer prevention and treatment.
results_summary: Higenamine and its derivatives, particularly compound 7c, showed potent antibacterial activity against F. nucleatum, inhibited CRC cell migration induced by F. nucleatum, and impaired biofilm and cell wall integrity.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: MIC50 = 0.005 μM for compound 7c (specific dosage not provided for higenamine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higenamine (HG) could act as an osteogenic agent and potential therapeutic candidate for osteoporosis by targeting the SMAD2/3 pathway.
results_summary: HG effectively induced osteogenic markers in mouse bone marrow stromal cells and preosteoblastic cells, enhanced bone formation, and prevented bone loss in animal models of senile and postmenopausal osteoporosis. It was found to bind to IQGAP1, promoting SMAD2/3 phosphorylation and inhibiting SMAD4 ubiquitination.
population_specificity: Mouse bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs), preosteoblastic cells, and animal models of osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the role of higenamine in heart diseases, including its pharmacological mechanisms and clinical applications.
results_summary: Higenamine showed potential in improving energy metabolism, reducing cardiac fibrosis, and alleviating heart failure through multiple signaling pathways. Clinical studies noted its ability to increase heart rate, though effects on blood pressure were variable.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers and patients with heart disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate higenamine's potential as a bronchodilator and its effects on allergic asthma symptoms, including airway hyper-responsiveness (AHR) and mucus production.
results_summary: Higenamine reduced AHR, IL-4, IL-13 levels, mucus-related gene expression, and mucus hypersecretion but had no significant effect on IL-5, INF-γ, IgE, LTB4, LTC4 levels, or eosinophilic inflammation. It controlled asthma acute attacks and breathlessness but did not notably affect inflammation.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with induced allergic asthma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the ergogenic effects and safety profile of a one-component higenamine supplement in female recreational athletes.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in cardiopulmonary parameters, weight loss, or safety outcomes between the higenamine and placebo groups after 21 days of supplementation. Higenamine was deemed safe and well-tolerated but did not improve exercise fitness or weight loss.
population_specificity: Female recreational basketball players aged 29-41 with VO2max > 30 ml⋅kg-1⋅min-1 and training > 5 h wk-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacological effects of higenamine and its potential clinical applications, focusing on its cardiovascular benefits and other therapeutic properties.
results_summary: Higenamine acts as a non-selective β-agonist, improving heart rate, myocardial contractility, and bronchodilation, with potential benefits for weight loss, anti-inflammatory effects, and antioxidant properties. However, its clinical use is limited by insufficient long-term safety and pharmacokinetic data, and it is banned by the World Anti-Doping Agency due to stimulant effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effect and mechanism of Higenamine (Hig) on neuropathic pain (NP) by evaluating its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and pain-relief properties.
results_summary: Hig demonstrated significant antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, reducing ROS, MDA, TNF-α, and IL-6 levels while increasing SOD and GSH levels. It also alleviated pain in CCI-induced NP model rats, suggesting its neuroprotective effect may involve the NOX2/ROS/TRP/P38 MAPK/NF-ĸB pathway.
population_specificity: Chronic constrict injury (CCI) model rats and t-BHP-induced Schwann cells (SCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Higenamine on allergic rhinitis and investigate its underlying mechanism of action.
results_summary: Higenamine significantly alleviated symptoms of allergic rhinitis in mice, reduced IgE and histamine levels, and modulated immune responses. It also inhibited inflammatory markers and signaling pathways in human nasal epithelial cells.
population_specificity: Ovalbumin-induced allergic rhinitis mouse model and human nasal epithelial cells (HNEpCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate higenamine as a selective LSD1 inhibitor and assess its epigenetic regulatory effects and therapeutic potential in MLL-rearranged leukemia cells.
results_summary: Higenamine demonstrated potent LSD1 inhibition, increased expression of H3K4me1/2, suppressed HOXA9 and MEIS1 levels, induced cell differentiation, promoted apoptosis, and inhibited colony formation in leukemia cells without significantly affecting proliferation.
population_specificity: MLL-rearranged leukemia cell lines (MV4-11 and MOLM-13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects and potential mechanism of higenamine combined with [6]-gingerol against doxorubicin-induced chronic heart failure in rats.
results_summary: HG/[6]-GR improved hemodynamic indices, alleviated serum biochemical indicators, reduced myocardial cell apoptosis, and regulated metabolites and pathways related to energy metabolism. The combination showed significant therapeutic effects on CHF in rats.
population_specificity: Rats with doxorubicin-induced chronic heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish the efficacy and safety of a standardized aqueous extract of Hibiscus Sabdariffa L. in treating anemia in adults.
results_summary: The study found that the extract did not improve iron status in anemic adults in a malaria-endemic region, but it demonstrated safety for human consumption. The extract's iron and organic acid content suggested potential for improving hematopoietic parameters, though further studies are needed.
population_specificity: Adults (men and women) aged 18-50 years with anemia in a malaria-endemic region (Mkuranga district).
effective_dosage: 1000ml, 1500ml, and 2000ml of aqueous extract orally; 200mg ferrous sulphate tablet as a comparator.
